SpNote.note: WFCAM observing protocol calls for an hourly standard star MSB to be carried out. In general, this should be your source of all calibrations. Notably, photometry and astrometry but also if you stick to "standard" exposure times you should also use the darks from these. If you vary the exposure time, then you will need to insert your own darks.
SpNote.title: Calibrations

SpNote.note:
These MSBs contain a single telescope pointing. They are usefull if you are basically using one of the WFCAM arrays to image a large object or field that is contained within the coverage of that array and are either disregarding the other arrays or are using them as controll fields or similar.
IMPORTANT: Note that the co-ordinates you specify in the target component are for the centre of the wfcam focal plane. This DOES NOT CORRESPOND TO THE CENTRE OF ANY OF THE ARRAYS.
The centres of the arrays are offset from the centre of the wfcam focal plane by approximately 800 arcseconds in both RA and Dec.
The recipe in these sequences (JITTER) assumes that you will have a seperate flat field. If you wish to self flat, change the recipe name to JITTER_SELF_FLAT
SpNote.title: Single filter "paw print" MSBs

SpNote.note:
IMPORTANT: Note that the co-ordinates you specify in the target component are for the centre of the wfcam focal plane. This DOES NOT CORRESPOND TO THE CENTRE OF ANY OF THE ARRAYS.
The centres of the arrays are offset from the centre of the wfcam focal plane by approximately 800 arcseconds in both RA and Dec.
SpNote.title: Target information - IMPORTANT

SpNote.note: The recipe in these sequences (JITTER) assumes that you will have a seperate flat field. If you wish to self flat, change the recipe name to JITTER_SELF_FLAT
SpNote.title: DRrecipe

SpNote.note:
Set filters and exposure times etc in the WFCAM component.
In general, we advocate sticking to 5s exposures for J, H, K. Microstepping and small offsets are very efficient with WFCAM, so in general we advocate doing a small offset pattern rather than several coadds.
SpNote.title: WFCAM component

SpNote.note: If you are using a "non standard" exposure time, you will need to insert some darks here. I recomend adding 3 to 5 darks if you need them.
SpNote.title: DARKS

SpNote.note:
This pattern aims to offset an integer number of IR pixels as the image may not be oversampled. Also the offsets are an integer number of AG pixels - otherwise the guider will pull it into an integer number anyway and introduce bad offsets.
In addition, we distort the pattern from a simple square or die-5 shape so as to avoid any part of the sky staying on a bad row or column. This accounts for the somewhat distorted shape of the pattern.
In this pattern, the seperation betwen the "corner" positions is approx 10 arcsec. This pattern is best suited to the "small" microstepping patterns. This pattern is probably too small to use in self-flat observations. This pattern should allways be able to use fast offsetting.
SpNote.title: Offset Pattern

SpNote.note: If you wish to use microstepping, go into the microstep itterator below and select the pattern you wish to use. 2x2 small is a good default. The different "NxN small" patterns do the microstepping in different orders, to avoid persistant image buildup.
SpNote.title: MicroSteps

SpNote.note:
IMPORTANT: Note that the co-ordinates you specify in the target component are for the centre of the wfcam focal plane. This DOES NOT CORRESPOND TO THE CENTRE OF ANY OF THE ARRAYS.
The centres of the arrays are offset from the centre of the wfcam focal plane by approximately 800 arcseconds in both RA and Dec.
SpNote.title: Target information - IMPORTANT

SpNote.note: The recipe in these sequences (JITTER) assumes that you will have a seperate flat field. If you wish to self flat, change the recipe name to JITTER_SELF_FLAT
SpNote.title: DRrecipe

SpNote.note:
Set filters and exposure times etc in the WFCAM component.
In general, we advocate sticking to 5s exposures for J, H, K. Microstepping and small offsets are very efficient with WFCAM, so in general we advocate doing a small offset pattern rather than several coadds.
SpNote.title: WFCAM component

SpNote.note: If you are using a "non standard" exposure time, you will need to insert some darks here. I recomend adding 3 to 5 darks if you need them.
SpNote.title: DARKS

SpNote.note:
This pattern aims to offset an integer number of IR pixels as the image may not be oversampled. Also the offsets are an integer number of AG pixels - otherwise the guider will pull it into an integer number anyway and introduce bad offsets.
Each row or column is only used at most twice to minimise the effect of bad rows or columns.
In this pattern, the seperation betwen the "corner" positions is approx 13 arcsec. This pattern is best suited to the "small" microstepping patterns. This pattern is probably too small to use in self-flat observations. This pattern should allways be able to use fast offsetting.
SpNote.title: Offset Pattern

SpNote.note: If you wish to use microstepping, go into the microstep itterator below and select the pattern you wish to use. 2x2 small is a good default. The different "NxN small" patterns do the microstepping in different orders, to avoid persistant image buildup.
SpNote.title: MicroSteps

SpNote.note:
IMPORTANT: Note that the co-ordinates you specify in the target component are for the centre of the wfcam focal plane. This DOES NOT CORRESPOND TO THE CENTRE OF ANY OF THE ARRAYS.
The centres of the arrays are offset from the centre of the wfcam focal plane by approximately 800 arcseconds in both RA and Dec.
SpNote.title: Target information - IMPORTANT

SpNote.note: The recipe in these sequences (JITTER) assumes that you will have a seperate flat field. If you wish to self flat, change the recipe name to JITTER_SELF_FLAT

SpNote.note:
This pattern aims to offset an integer number of IR pixels as the image may not be oversampled. Also the offsets are an integer number of AG pixels - otherwise the guider will pull it into an integer number anyway and introduce bad offsets.

In this pattern, the seperation betwen the "corner" positions is approx 20 arcsec. This pattern is best suited to the "small" microstepping patterns. This pattern should allways be able to use fast offsetting.
SpNote.title: Offset Pattern

SpNote.note: If you wish to use microstepping, go into the microstep itterator below and select the pattern you wish to use. 2x2 small is a good default. The different "NxN small" patterns do the microstepping in different orders, to avoid persistant image buildup.
SpNote.title: MicroSteps

SpNote.note:
IMPORTANT: Note that the co-ordinates you specify in the target component are for the centre of the wfcam focal plane. This DOES NOT CORRESPOND TO THE CENTRE OF ANY OF THE ARRAYS.
The centres of the arrays are offset from the centre of the wfcam focal plane by approximately 800 arcseconds in both RA and Dec.
SpNote.title: Target information - IMPORTANT

SpNote.note: The recipe in these sequences (JITTER) assumes that you will have a seperate flat field. If you wish to self flat, change the recipe name to JITTER_SELF_FLAT
SpNote.title: DRrecipe

SpNote.note:
Set filters and exposure times etc in the WFCAM component.
In general, we advocate sticking to 5s exposures for J, H, K. Microstepping and small offsets are very efficient with WFCAM, so in general we advocate doing a small offset pattern rather than several coadds.
SpNote.title: WFCAM component

SpNote.note: If you are using a "non standard" exposure time, you will need to insert some darks here. I recomend adding 3 to 5 darks if you need them.
SpNote.title: DARKS

SpNote.note:
This pattern aims to offset an integer number of IR pixels as the image may not be oversampled. Also the offsets are an integer number of AG pixels - otherwise the guider will pull it into an integer number anyway and introduce bad offsets.
Each row or column is only used three times to help deal with bad columns or rows.
In this pattern, the seperation betwen the "corner" positions is approx 20 arcsec. This pattern is best suited to the "small" microstepping patterns. This pattern should allways be able to use fast offsetting.
SpNote.title: Offset Pattern

SpNote.note: If you wish to use microstepping, go into the microstep itterator below and select the pattern you wish to use. 2x2 small is a good default. The different "NxN small" patterns do the microstepping in different orders, to avoid persistant image buildup.
SpNote.title: MicroSteps

SpNote.note:
These MSBs can be used as input to the SDT for carrying out surveys. You can also fill in the list of pointings in the survey container by hand.
Note. If you want to survey a small area in several filters, create seperate MSBs for each filter, or at least seperate observations in a seperate survey container - if you put a filter itterator inside the observation in these MSBs you will incur huge overheads from filter changes, each of which takes ~30 secs.
SpNote.title: Survey MSBs

SpNote.note: The recipe in these sequences (JITTER) assumes that you will have a seperate flat field. If you wish to self flat, change the recipe name to JITTER_SELF_FLAT
SpNote.title: DRrecipe

SpNote.note:
Set filters and exposure times etc in the WFCAM component.
In general, we advocate sticking to 5s exposures for J, H, K. Microstepping and small offsets are very efficient with WFCAM, so in general we advocate doing a small offset pattern rather than several coadds.
SpNote.title: WFCAM component

SpNote.note: If you are using a "non standard" exposure time, you will need to insert some darks here. I recomend adding 3 to 5 darks if you need them.
SpNote.title: DARKS

SpNote.note:
This pattern aims to offset an integer number of IR pixels as the image may not be oversampled. Also the offsets are an integer number of AG pixels - otherwise the guider will pull it into an integer number anyway and introduce bad offsets.
In addition, we distort the pattern from a simple square or die-5 shape so as to avoid any part of the sky staying on a bad row or column. This accounts for the somewhat distorted shape of the pattern.
In this pattern, the seperation betwen the "corner" positions is approx 10 arcsec. This pattern is best suited to the "small" microstepping patterns. This pattern is probably too small to use in self-flat observations. This pattern should allways be able to use fast offsetting.
SpNote.title: Offset Pattern

SpNote.note: If you wish to use microstepping, go into the microstep itterator below and select the pattern you wish to use. 2x2 small is a good default. The different "NxN small" patterns do the microstepping in different orders, to avoid persistant image buildup.
SpNote.title: MicroSteps
